Gerber Products Company - Fort Smith Risk Management Plan for Anhydrous Ammonia

Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



Gerber Products Company in Fort Smith, Arkansas, a Nestle company, has maintained a management / safety committee at the site for many years. Gerber is committed to performing "Due Diligence", which means taking all reasonable care to protect the health and safety of its employees, the community and the environment. This is especially true when it comes to chemical use and safety, including our PSM / RMP process for Anhydrous Ammonia for our refrigeration system.



Gerber has, and continues, to take steps to ensure we move forward as a World Class manufacturing facility. These steps include:



Developing Health, Safety and Environmental policies, procedures, programs, rules and regulations.



Implementing policies in the facility with the commitment of senior management and involvement of our workers.



Ensuring that Emergency Response procedures are developed, trained and adhered to at all levels of the organization, including our:



?    Hazardous Materials Team, for responding to potential leaks or spills of hazardous chemicals.

?    NEM team, (Nestle Emergency Management), for understanding, managing, communicating, documenting and reporting potential adverse issues.



Planning for contingencies through:

?    Compliance with legislation

?    Involvement of our employees at all levels

?    Training and development of employees

?    Preventive maintenance programs

?    Understanding and reducing potential risks through development of risk portfolios

?    Identification of process hazards and implementation of controls to eliminate or control these hazards with the use of ZHA, (Zurich Hazard Analysis).



Our Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled:



Gerber Products Company, Fort Smith, is the premier manufacturer of baby food, including wet, jarred fruits, vegetables and meats, meat sticks and dry cere

al products. We have our own maintenance, boiler room, waste water treatment, warehouse / shipping and refrigeration departments.



One independent "covered process" is present at the facility and has been identified based upon federal RMP regulations.  It is called "Ammonia System 2" because it replaced an older system in 2009, which was subsequently removed.  



Management activities are required under the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program for Accidental Release Prevention (40 CFR 68.15).  Our refrigeration department utilizes anhydrous ammonia (the only PSM / RMP regulated substance on-site) to maintain required temperatures for storage of raw ingredient materials.  At Gerber, Fort Smith, the SHE Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP program elements into the facility's safety program. The SHE department is part of the site NEM team.



While the site SHE Manger has overall responsibility for implementation of the RMP, the PSM, an integral part of our RMP, is overseen by a team comprised of our Utility

Manager, Ammonia Refrigeration Technicians and the SHE Mgr. The individuals on this team have the responsibility for performing the duties that are detailed in the Fort Smith Plant's Process Safety Management Program.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps:



Anticipating and managing risk is an essential element of doing business today, particularly for companies that manufacture, store, process and / or transport potentially harmful chemical substances. Safety is a priority at all Nestle Corporation facilities, including Gerber, Fort Smith, where emergency planning and preparation are a fundamental part of our business.



Our Risk Management Planning, (RMP), considers such factors as:

?    The potential effects of chemical releases;

?    The five-year history of a facility's accidental chemical releases;

?    The facility's prog

ram for preventing accidents;

?    The facility's program for responding in an emergency.



Managing risk involves making our facility safe through technology and design. Our advanced Process Safety Management programs and emergency response systems include:

?    Mechanical integrity program

?    Safety controls

?    Computers / control systems

?    Regular equipment inspections

?    Operator training

?    Leak detectors

?    Pressure safety valves

?    Warning alarms

?    Automatic control valves

?    Standard operating procedures

?    Emergency operating procedures

?    Emergency shutdown procedures



We will constantly strive to improve equipment and processes in our facility.



Our Five-Year Accident History:



We have not had any accidental releases which have resulted in any on-site or off-site consequences to people, the community or the environment in the last five years.



Our Emergency Response Program:



The Gerber Fort Smith facility maintains an Emergency Response Plan to ensure preparedness in the unlikely event of an accident. Our plan is designed to control the impact and severity of any possible chemical accidents. Gerber participates with the local emergency planning committee, (LEPC), of Sebastian County and is included within their written Emergency Response Plan.



The written Emergency Response Plan includes:

?    Procedures to inform the public and local emergency response agencies;

?    Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment;

?    Procedures to measure emergency response after an incident;

?    Emergency response equipment and procedures for its use, inspection, testing and maintenance;

?    Employee training;

?    Procedures to review and update the Emergency Response Plan and inform employees of changes.

?    Coordination with Local Emergency Response Agencies

?    Public and Media Relations

?    Documentation and Records Management



We maintain an active Hazmat team, whose members have gone through 40-hours of initial training and 8-hours of annua

l refresher training.



Our site NEM, (Nestle Emergency Management), team is comprised of the individuals with the expertise to manage any crisis that may occur. The NEM team at the site can request assistance from either a Sector Company NEM team member or a Corporate NEM team member if needed.



In summary, while the primary organization at the plant site is the NEM, there are significant other resources available to respond to the needs of the Fort Smith site.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



?    Each year, Gerber reviews the Emergency Response Plan and conducts drills based on preplanned release criteria and scenarios.

?    Each year, monies are budgeted to ensure our ammonia refrigeration systems and mechanical integrity is properly maintained.

?    We perform prescribed audits and evaluations of our PSM and RMP, address issues and strive to continually improve our process.

?    We will continue to monitor our plant site and chemical systems to ensure the safe operation of the Fort Smith Facility.
